article.title: Sex-specific cardiovascular adaptations to simulated microgravity in Sprague-Dawley rats
funding: WFUSM Cardiovascular Sciences Center Pilot Award
R. Odell Farley Hudson Research Fund
Hypertension and Vascular Research Center of Wake Forest University School of Medicine (WFUSM)
article.abstract: Men and women have different cardiovascular responses to spaceflight; however, few studies have focused on direct comparisons between sexes. We investigated the mechanisms of aortic stiffening in socially and sexually mature 20-week-old male and female Sprague Dawley (SD) rats exposed to hindlimb unloading (HLU) for 14 days.

sections.introduction: The cardiovascular adaptations in astronauts both during and after spaceflight are variable in terms of sex, duration of exposure, and the model used for the studies.
sections.methods: The study was approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of the Wake Forest University School of Medicine (A21-039).
sections.results: The body weight of male control rats was significantly (p < 0.05) greater than the body weight of female control rats (Fig. 1).
sections.discussion: Recent studies highlighted the incidence of arterial stiffness in astronauts following spaceflight. The exposure of rodents to ground-based analogs of microgravity via HLU also demonstrated development of arterial stiffness.

article.insights_summary: This study highlights sex-specific vascular adaptations to the state of simulated microgravity. Female SD rats exposed to HLU had a greater aortic arch PWV compared to control females or HLU males. The levels of G protein-coupled estrogen receptor (GPER) were lower in the aorta of SD females exposed to HLU compared with female controls.
article.acknowledgments: These studies were supported by the WFUSM Cardiovascular Sciences Center Pilot Award to L.M.Y., R. Odell Farley Hudson Research Fund, and the Hypertension and Vascular Research Center of Wake Forest University School of Medicine (WFUSM).
